sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; (gst-mixer) is a GNOME enabled audio mixer. &app; allows you to mix audio for various sound cards.

To run &app; select
Multimedia Audio Mixer
from the Main Menu, or type gst-mixer on the command line.
&app; is included in the gnome-media package, which is part of the GNOME desktop environment. This document describes version &version; of &app;.

sect1.title: Using GNOME Volume Control
sect1.para:
There are four main components to &app;: the faders, Mute buttons, Rec. buttons, and the Lock buttons. The Lock locks the left and right channels together so that you can adjust either fader and both will be syncronized. If you have unlocked the faders and moved them apart, then press the lock button the faders will resyncronize. Meaning you can't lock the faders in an unequal position. The Mute silences the channel.
The last button, Rec. is toggled to turn on/off the recording functions of your soundcard on that channel. The faders control the volume of each channel. Below is a listing of what each fader represents. GNOME Volume control has its interface generated dynamically based on the specifications of your soundcard. This means that the mixer on your desktop will not look exactly like the one in the screenshot. The mixer in the screenshot is for a Sound Blaster Live card. Depending on your card and sound system you might have fewer or more controls in your mixer.

listitem.para: Vol — This is the main volume fader.
Synth — This fader controls the volume of the midi devices.
Pcm — This fader controls the "wave" files.
Spkr — This fader controls the Speaker output jack.
Line — This is the Line input on your sound card, if you have one.
Mic — This is the Microphone input on your sound card.
CD — This is the CD player input gain.
Rec — This is the overall Record level fader. (Master Record level)
Line2 — If your sound card has a second line input this is the fader that controls the volume.

sect1.title: Known Bugs and Limitations
sect1.para: Using the ALSA sound system there might be a very large number of channels. We don't have a proper solution for that yet. Apart from that no known bugs at this time.

sect1.title: About &app;
sect1.para: Gnome Volume Control was written by Ronald Bultje (rbultje@ronald.bitfreak.net). Please send all comments, suggestions, and bug reports to the GNOME bug tracking database. (Instructions for submitting bug reports can be found on-line.) If you are using GNOME 1.1 or later, you can also use Bug Report Tool (bug-buddy), available in the Utilities submenu of Main Menu, for submitting bug reports.

The first version of this manual was written by Erik Jarvi (ejarvi@megsinet.net) and updated by Michael Froh (msfroh@uwaterloo.ca). Based on the original manual Christian Fredrik Kalager Schaller (uraeus@gnome.org) rewrote it to be used with the new mixer in GNOME 2.6.
